title: Cat. 83  The Little Balcony, 1894
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 831894Way: 50  
Levy: 81  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on fine-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, lower right  
One state; image size: 201 × 157 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 28  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 41, 42, 151, 166  
Posthumous edition: 35 impressions printed by Goulding on 11 December 1903  
Posthumous watermarks: 15, 18, 19, 37, 112, 165, 219, 220  
Stone: erased in 1903  
Whistler-Way Letters: 88, 90, 93; apps. I.1, II.3, II.4, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Way, Studio (1896), p. 224; Way (1912), pp. 93–94  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (no. 2, as The Balcony); New York 1898 (no. 319); London 1898–99? (no. 1996, as The Balcony); Chicago 1900b (no. 46)

Whistler sketched this image and The Long Balcony (cat. 82) from a window overlooking the rue de Rivoli on the morning of 1 July 1894, as the funeral cortege of the slain French president, Carnot, passed through the streets of Paris. The animated, sun-drenched scenes suggest that the somber occasion nevertheless had its festive side, as spectators crowded to windows and balconies to watch the spectacle. Both of the “Paris Windows,” as Whistler and Rosalind Birnie Philip frequently referred to these subjects, appeal to twentieth-century viewers for their directness and spontaneity. However, they were not popular during the artist’s lifetime. No impressions of either subject sold during the Fine Art Society’s 1895–96 exhibition of his lithographs, and the majority of the impressions printed by the Ways were still in Whistler’s possession at the time of his death.

Chicago: AIC, cream laid Japanese vellum (331 × 241 mm), signed; MWC, cream laid Japanese vellum (333 × 239 mm), signed; SC, cream laid Japanese vellum (332 × 240 mm). Glasgow: HAG (9), cream laid Japanese vellum (336 × 235 mm), signed; cream laid Japanese vellum (328 × 238 mm), signed; cream laid Japanese vellum (338 × 240 mm); cream laid Japanese vellum (336 × 236 mm); cream laid Japanese vellum (333 × 238 mm); golden-yellow Japanese paper (303 × 231 mm), signed; ivory laid paper (323 × 208 mm), signed; tan laid Japanese vellum (317 × 230 mm), signed; tan laid Japanese vellum (332 × 236 mm). London: BM, cream laid paper (283 × 224 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid Japanese vellum (330 × 241 mm), signed; NGA, cream laid Japanese vellum (335 × 239 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Ann Arbor, UMMA; Brooklyn, TBM; and Cleveland, CMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">GUL LB6; transcribed in MacDonald (1988), p. 42.
